content.question: Which of the following experimental designs would best allow researchers to investigate the effect of <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the rate of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction?

choices.label: Measure reaction rates at different <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels when the enzyme concentration remains the same and the substrate concentration is <math alttext="100 micromolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn><mtext> </mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext></mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">μ</mi><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Measure the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the reaction mixture when the enzyme concentration remains the same and substrate concentrations vary between <math alttext="0 micromolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">μ</mi><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="1,000 micromolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">μ</mi><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Measure reaction rates when the enzyme concentration remains the same but the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the reaction mixture increases and the substrate concentration increases from <math alttext="0 micromolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext> </mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">μ</mi><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="1,000 micromolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">μ</mi><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Measure reaction rates when the substrate concentration is <math alttext="100 micromolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">μ</mi><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and both the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the reaction mixture and the enzyme concentration are increased.

content.answer: Measure reaction rates at different <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> levels when the enzyme concentration remains the same and the substrate concentration is <math alttext="100 micromolar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn><mtext> </mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext></mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">μ</mi><mtext>M</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 3.D: Propose a new investigation based on an evaluation of the experimental design or evidence.
